paragraphs.text: For me, the most interesting part is the overlap and changes that occur on this map. For example, #blacklivesmatter started as a Flock (through the use of #Ferguson, #Charleston, and #BaltimoreProtests hashtags) and is now transitioning closer and closer to the Tribe stage as people start to form relationships and build movements around this civil rights cause.
paragraphs.name: 03a3

paragraphs.text: This is awesome. One additional insight from me is that these all co-exist and that’s part of what makes them valuable. Thanks for making this.
paragraphs.name: e3a2

paragraphs.text: Rahaf, fascinating article. While this has not been a major area of personal study, for quite some time I’ve been interested in online interaction and the ultimate creation of online communities that grow out of that interaction. My own personal experience dates back to 1983 with the formation of the National University Teleconference Network (NUTN…

paragraphs.text: I love this especially when I think the different uses for social networks like Twitter vs. Facebook vs. Snapchat as well as blogs and an email newsletter. These allow for different types of intimacy and engagement levels. All have benefits but fall within your four categories most often.

I’ve seen his amazing talk and have incorporated into my own work around the Digital Culture of cities. I love the innovation and great ideas that are happening in this space…

paragraphs.text: Rahaf: Great stuff! This reminds me so much of Charlie Ledbeater — I call him the master of the quadrant ;-). http://charlesleadbeater.net Do you two know each other? Here’s hoping you cross paths. And come back to Portland one of these days, would you? About to explore Hustle & Float, thanks for the reminder…

I could also see this being applied as a way to check the overall marketing efforts to make sure they are operating in…

paragraphs.text: Very cool. I also think that the interesting bit is where a “community” might develop and migrate from one area on the map to another. Looking at that with my strategy hat on gets me very excited because, as an example, moving a community started around a brand/service/product from a flock to a tribe would surely go down as some sort of success.
paragraphs.name: 8f59

paragraphs.text: Thanks for this article, Rahaf! I’ve learned that I’ve always been someone who loves to be part of a tribe. As a community manager I thus focus on creating a tribe. The community I’m responsible for now discusses a highly intimate subject (sexuality) but I’ve witnessed different types of behaviour by members. We have the typical tribe members but…

paragraphs.text: So if you created an online space to co-create an upcoming conference (eg., via commentable/votable submissions to a Call for Ideas or Papers), and then successfully transitioned the resulting temporary community into a longer-lived one, would that be from Single Serve to a Tribe?

In assessing the importance of visual communication (still images and video) it would be interesting to see what kinds of images and what kind of visual storytelling dominate the different quadrants; for example, would the instagram-only person (ecosystem) be different than a Facebook…

996106d7287e.title: Rahaf, this is a very good piece of work, it’s sounded, I share the enthusiasm for mapping out the…

paragraphs.text: Rahaf, this is a very good piece of work, it’s sounded, I share the enthusiasm for mapping out the online community. With these quandrant now in mind, I’d like to break them down in particular to highlight the churn rate, but the evil is (often) in the details. I’ll watch your space.
paragraphs.name: 472f

7689af83538a.title: A third dimension could be frequency of activity.

paragraphs.text: A third dimension could be frequency of activity. You would expect a correlation between intimacy and frequency, but this is not always the case. There are digital spaces with deep member-to-member connections with intermittent communication — thinking of old-fashioned school listserv (mailing lists) with a high signal to noise ratio….
paragraphs.name: bc3c

paragraphs.text: Very nice. I will incorporate this thinking into my Twitter analysis. I have used a definition of Tribes in pretty much the same way but the other definitions are all visible in my maps. Just need to work out the algorithms for detection! https://medium.com/@swainjo/nhs-debate-on-twitter-one-month-data-91319352b3c#.hcoe4whi9

a0adecb18147.title: I’d say it’s closer from a Flock to a tribe, because the conference would be a good time-sensitive…

paragraphs.text: I’d say it’s closer from a Flock to a tribe, because the conference would be a good time-sensitive event that would temporarily rally people on social media for its duration (via shares, tweets, coverage, etc) and then after the event it could either transition to ecosystem or a tribe depending on the intimacy level of the community.
paragraphs.name: 70f1
